title: Frida Kahlo’s Works to Headline Christie’s Latin American Art Auctions
text:
Text size

Two paintings by Mexican painter Frida Kahlo, who has been one of the most sought-after Latin American artists for decades, will lead Christie’s New York sales of Latin American art in November.

Both works, The Flower Basket and Portrait of a Lady in White, are estimated to sell for between $3 and $5 million.

The Flower Basket was executed in 1941, just after Kahlo (1907-1954) and painter Diego Rivera remarried after a brief divorce. “This exuberant and colorful painting celebrates Kahlo’s love of nature as well as a particularly happy moment of her life,” Christie’s said.

The tondo, or circular-shaped painting on copper, was first acquired from Kahlo by American actress Paulette Goddard, a friend of the artist couple. It’s offered for sale this time from the collection of James and Marilyn Alsdorf, prominent business owners and art patrons in Chicago.

Portrait of a Lady in White was offered for sale—the first time on the auction block—from the William Louis-Dreyfus Foundation, with proceeds benefiting the late philanthropist’s eponymous foundation and The Harlem Children's Zone.

Louis-Dreyfus, heir to Louis Dreyfus Group, a global merchant firm that does business in agriculture, food processing, international shipping, and finance, died in 2016 at age 84.

The oil-on-canvas portrait was painted around the time of Kahlo’s marriage to Rivera in 1929. It was initially gifted by the artist to Mexican photographer Lola Álvarez Bravo, L and was on extended loan to Stanford University from The William Louis-Dreyfus Foundation.

Frida Kahlo's Portrait of a Lady in White Courtesy of Christie's

Kahlo was the first Latin-American artist to cross the million-dollar threshold with her 1949 painting Diego y Yo, which netted $1.4 million at Sotheby’s in May 1990. In 2016, her 1939 painting Two Nudes in the Forest (The Earth Itself) sold at Christie’s New York for $8 million, the highest price for any Latin American artist. Later in May 2018, Rivera claimed the title with the sale of his painting The Rivals, which fetched $9.8 million at a Christie’s auction of the collection of David and Peggy Rockefeller.

Another highlight of Christie’s sale of Latin American art, which will take place at its Rockefeller Center galleries from Nov. 20 to 22 and online from Nov. 16 to 26, is Fernando Botero’s Tablao Flamenco.

Executed in 1984, this work is one of the most important paintings by the artist to come to auction in recent years. It has a presale estimate of between $1.5 million and $2 million. Complementing this piece is a robust selection of works by the Colombian master that includes paintings, drawings, and exquisite sculptures.

Additionally, the sale will feature Latin American works from other important private collections, including The Collection of Dr. Helga Prignitz-Poda, The Collection of Richard L. Weisman, and The Collection of James Li, ranging from 17th- and 18th-century Spanish colonial paintings through modern and contemporary masterpieces.

Together, the sales are expected to realize in excess of $25 million.

A preview of select works will begin on Nov. 16 at Christie’s Rockefeller Center galleries in New York.
